question: A patient of schizophrenia treated for 5 years developed perioral movements. Likely diagnosis is:
exp: Ans. A. Tardive dyskinesia. Tardive dyskinesia is the abnormal movement of tongue, lips or buccal cavity after long time intake of antipsychotic drug intake. It develops after minimum of six months of antipsychotic intake.

question: Normal therapeutic level of Lithium is:
exp: Ans: B (0. 7 - 1. 1 m. Eq/L) Lithium. Short Review. The peak serum levels occur between 30 minutes to 3 hours. The absorption is virtually complete in about 8 hours. Lithium is not protein bound: There is no metabolism of, litium in body. It is excreted almost entirely by kidneys. Tremor: This is the commonest side effect*, occurring in up to 50% of patients. The most serious (though uncommon! side-effects are hepatic toxicity (especially in children), acute hemorrhagic pancreatitis, and Steven Johnson syndrome. The exact mechanism of action is not known. Before starting treatment, it is essential to make sure of normal functioning of kidneys (most important), thyroid, heart and central nervous system. The side-effects are common and toxicity occurs easily; if blood level reach about 2. 0 m. Eq/L. Lite-tberatening intoxication occurs, if levels reach about 3. 5 m. Eq/L. question: Akathesia is characterized by -
exp: Ans. is 'a' i. e. Restlessness, persistant desire to move about, and fidgety & rocking movement o Akathisia is characterized by restlessness, inability to sit/stand quietly, persistant desire to move about, and fidgety & rocking movement. o Tongue protrusion, stiffness, oculogyric crisis and abnormal posture of trunk and limbs suggest the diagnosis of acute muscular dystonia. o Purposeless involuntary facial and limb movements, constant chewing and puffing of checks suggest the diagnosis of tardive dyskinesia. o Perioral tremors are known as Rabbit syndrome.
